slidelink.displaytext: Correlation, Causation, and Decision-Making (Total Session Length: 38:21)
The Salesman Problem: Conditioning on Data (0:46)
Applying Bayes Law: Base Rate Fallacy (2:28)
Applying Bayes Law: The Monty Hall Problem (3:43)

search.slidetext: correlation, causation, and decision-making daniel l. goroff funded by a grant from the www.thegovlab.org
daniel l. goroff

if i do x, can i expect y? a claim about how treatment x causes an outcome y. different from saying that x and y are observed to vary in association with one another (correlation). need to ask 5 questions when deciding based on data. session outline condition probability of y given x condition probability of y given x independence of x and y independence of x and y association of x and y association of x and y causal inference about how x affects y causal inference about how x affects y statistical significance of results about x and y statistical significance of results about x and y
the salesman problem tom is either a salesman or a librarian you find out that he has a quiet personality which is more likely, s or l?

salesman salesman salesman salesman salesman salesman librarian librarian librarian librarian librarian librarian the salesman problem tom is either a salesman or librarian. you find out he has a quiet personality. which is more likely, s or l? i.e., which is bigger: pr (s | q) or pr (l | q) select your answer: probability of s(alesman) given q(uiet) pr (s | q)

the salesman problem large “conditional probability” that tom is quiet given that he is a librarian, of course. but say fred is either a salesman or a librarian. you know nothing else. now which is more likely for fred, s or l? s or l salesman salesman salesman salesman salesman salesman salesman librarian librarian librarian librarian librarian librarian librarian
conditional probability imagine two events: a and b prob of a given b is: pr(red | blue) = ? pr(blue | red) = ?
bayesian updating prob of a given d is: bayes law: = likelihood ratio x base rate odds
applying bayes law base rate fallacy fred is either a salesman or a librarian? there are about 100x as many s as l in the us. so which is more likely for tom, s or l?
applying bayes law the monty hall problem one car, 2 goats, 3 doors. you pick a. monty opens b. should you switch to c? bayes says:

direction matters pr(x=x|y=y) differs from pr(y=y|x=x) “if x then y” differs from “if y then x.” does the fact that you eat grass necessarily mean that you are a cow? yes yes yes yes yes yes yes no no no no no no no

direction matters “if x then y” differs from “if y then x” q1: do statistics treat x and y symmetrically? in that case, you should worry that those statistics cannot answer your problem. see claims about associated variables.

what “independence” means means “not associated.” equivalent definitions: pr(a|b)=pr(a) pr(b|a)=pr(b) pr(a&b) = pr(a)pr(b) pr(a|b)/pr(a|~b)=1 (likelihood ratio) pr(a|b)-pr(a|~b)=0 (regression coefficient) notice a is independent of b, if and only if, b is independent of a. symmetry rather than direction.

hypothesis testing q5. do the data seem to support “statistically significant” findings? may not mean much if the findings are the result of “fishing.” significance: p-value = pr(data|null hypothesis)<0.5 if you try enough hypotheses, you’ll find something (spurious). beware of looking for “patterns.” big enough data sets will have them just due to chance, not due to causality. “surprising” streaks in 100 fair coin flips…

bayesian inference suppose data d says a given hypothesis is true. how good is the evidence? should you believe or act on it? recall pr(d|null) = p-value. in denominator of likelihood. numerator is pr(d|true) = “power.” ask about it, too!

do x, expect y, based on d? 1 do statistics treat x and y symmetrically? association does. it is a suggestive but not causal relation. 2 do the data describe the untreated? if not, get data that includes a comparison group. 3 do the data omit variables, relationships, and assumptions that could influence treatments or outcomes? the comparison group may be biased. 4 do the data generalize to describe the entire population of interest? use rcts, conditioning, etc. 5 do the data seem to support “statistically significant” findings? ask about fishing, power, not just p-values.

dependence if the relationship between two quantities is linear, it’s measured by correlation. correlation says that the quantities covary. if x is dependent on y, then y is dependent on x not a causal relationship. ice cream sales street crime time quantity
dependence ice cream sales street crime time quantity temperature

completeness dependence is suggestive, though. is pr(a|b) - pr(a|~b) different enough from zero? test the “null hypothesis” that it is zero… q2: do the data describe the untreated? if not, get data that includes a comparison group. pet theories from management focus magazine: 85% of ceos had a pet in high school! pr(dog|ceo) what about pr(dog|~ceo)? want pr(ceo|dog). or is that enough? what about stratification like ses?

simpson’s paradox q3: do the data omit variables, relationships, or assumptions that could influence treatments or outcomes? usually, so think harder. see simpson example from pearl. say 700 patients have access to a drug. say 350 take it. drug* no drug men 81 of 87 recovered (93%) 234 of 270 recovered (87%) women 192 of 263 recovered (73%) 55 of 80 recovered (69%) combined 273 of 350 recovered (78%) 289 of 350 recovered (83%) men do better with the drug women do, too. but people do worse?!

simpson’s paradox men do better with the drug women do, too. but they are less likely to recover regardless of the drug, and are more likely to take it. drug* no drug men 81 of 87 recovered (93%) 234 of 270 recovered (87%) women 192 of 263 recovered (73%) 55 of 80 recovered (69%) combined 273 of 350 recovered (78%) 289 of 350 recovered (83%)

same data, different rx exact same recovery data and table for 700 patients. lowering bp is how the treatment works, but it’s toxic, too. recommend the right column (taking the drug). data does not determine decision. drug* no drug men 81 of 87 recovered (93%) 234 of 270 recovered (87%) women 192 of 263 recovered (73%) 55 of 80 recovered (69%) combined 273 of 350 recovered (78%) 289 of 350 recovered (83%) no drug drug* low bp after 81 of 87 recovered (93%) 234 of 270 recovered (87%) high bp after 192 of 263 recovered (73%) 55 of 80 recovered (69%) combined 273 of 350 recovered (78%) 289 of 350 recovered (83%)

confounders q4. does the data generalize to describe the entire population of interest? pr(y=y|do(x)) describes when everyone gets x. average causal effect: pr(y=y|do(x)) - pr(y=y|do(~x)) z = gender x = drug y = recovery pr(y=y|x=x) differs from pr(y=y|do(x)) if confounders. rct makes potential outcome independent of treatment assignment, so that pr(y=y|x=x)=pr(y=y|do(x)) or “control for z” by conditioning on it:
